p: Moreover, the pooled results of the aforementioned meta-analysis from Barnes et al. demonstrated an association between influenza vaccination and a lower risk of composite CV events, with a pooled OR of 0.71 (95% CI: 0.56 to 0.91), equating to an estimated vaccine effectiveness of 29% (95% CI: 9% to 44%) against AMI [ 53]. This finding is in line with other results from another meta-analysis from Udell et al., which showed that the influenza vaccine given to high-risk patients, such as patients with CAD, reduced their risk of a major adverse cardiovascular event (MACE) (patients treated with influenza vaccine and MACE (2.9%) vs. patients treated with placebo or control and MACE (4.7%); RR, 0.64 (95% CI: 0.48â€“0.86), p = 0.003) [ 62]. Therefore, current European guidelines on the diagnosis and management of chronic coronary syndromes recommend annual influenza vaccination in order to improve prevention of AMI in patients with CAD and decrease CV mortality [ 63, 64, 65].
